htmlEmbed:
Several hundred ducks found dead from suspected bird flu along Lake Michigan@KadeHeather2/2/2025

The largest concentrations of sick mergansers were found Saturday at North Avenue Beach and Oak Street Beach. Other birds with symptoms were reported from Hyde Park to Wilmette between Friday and Sunday.

NewsRead

                email = event.params.email;
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.acquisitionCampaign != 'undefined') && (event.params.acquisitionCampaign.length > 0)) {
                acquisitionCampaign = event.params.acquisitionCampaign;
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.newsletter != 'undefined') && (event.params.newsletter.length > 0)) {
                newsletter = event.params.newsletter;
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.signupEndpoint != 'undefined') && (event.params.signupEndpoint.length > 0)) {
                signupEndpoint = event.params.signupEndpoint;
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.unblockDelay != 'undefined') && (event.params.unblockDelay.length > 0)) {
                unblockDelay = parseInt(event.params.unblockDelay);
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.cookieName != 'undefined') && (event.params.cookieName.length > 0)) {
                cookieName = event.params.cookieName;
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.cookieValue != 'undefined') && (event.params.cookieValue.length > 0)) {
                cookieValue = event.params.cookieValue;
            }
            if ((typeof event.params.gtmLabel != 'undefined') && (event.params.gtmLabel.length > 0)) {
                gtmLabel = event.params.gtmLabel;
            }
            // Validate Email
            if (!validateEmail(email)) {
                console.log("Invalid email");
                sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, false, 'Please provide a valid email', 'email');
            } else {
                // Execute the newsletter signup
                // Build formData object.
                var formData = new FormData();
                formData.append('email', email);
                formData.append('newsletter', newsletter);
                formData.append('acquisitionCampaign', acquisitionCampaign);
                fetch(signupEndpoint, {
                    body: formData,
                    method: "post"
                }).then(function(response) {
                    if (response.status == 200) {
                        pianoSetCustomVariableCookie(cookieName, cookieValue);
                        sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, true, 'subscribed', 'email');
                        setTimeout(unblockContent, unblockDelay);
                        // Send subscribe event to GTM
                        dataLayer.push({
                            "event": "e_NewsletterSignup",
                            "dl_Type": gtmLabel
                        });
                    } else {
                        sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, false, 'There was an error subscribing you.  Please try again later.', 'email');
                        dataLayer.push({
                            "event": "e_NewsletterError",
                            "dl_Type": gtmLabel
                        });
                    }
                });
                if ((typeof event.params.magicLinkEndpoint != 'undefined') && (event.params.magicLinkEndpoint.length > 0)) {
                    // do the magic link stuff
                    var magicLinkEndpoint = event.params.magicLinkEndpoint;
                    var formData = new FormData();
                    formData.append('email', email);
                    fetch(magicLinkEndpoint, {
                        body: formData,
                        method: "post"
                    }).then(function(response) {
                        // login the user
                    }).catch(function(error) {
                        console.log(error);
                    });
                }
            }
            break;
    }
}]);

/**
 * Function to send data upstream to Piano template
 * @param iframeId - Element id of the Piano iframe
 * @param success - true/false. Status of the message
 * @param message - Error message text
 * @param object - Additional data, like the the field that triggered the error
 */
function sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, success, message, object) {
    var iframe = document.querySelector('#' + iframeId);
    iframe.contentWindow.postMessage({
        piano: {
            success: success,
            message: message,
            object: object
        }
    }, '*');
}

/**
 * Sets cookie for later use in custom variables
 * @param name - Custom variable's name
 * @param value - Custom variable's value
 */
function pianoSetCustomVariableCookie(name, value) {
    // Get all existing values from the cookie
    var cookieValue = pianoReadCustomVariableCookie();
    // Set the value
    // cookieValue[name] = value;

    // Set cookie expiration date to 3 years
    var d = new Date();
    d.setTime(d.getTime() + (94608000000));
    var expires = "expires=" + d.toUTCString();

    // Write the cookie value
    document.cookie = `_pc_${name}=` + JSON.stringify(value) + ";" + expires + ";path=/";
}

/**
 * Read values from cookie and convert them from JSON
 * @param specificName (optional) Name specific value from the set
 * @returns {*} If specificName is specified - returns a single value, otherwise returns a JSON object with all values
 */
function pianoReadCustomVariableCookie(specificName) {
    var cookieValue;

    try {
        // Try to get the cookie value with regexp
        // var match = document.cookie.match(new RegExp('(^| )__pcvc=([^;]+)'));
        var match = document.cookie.match(new RegExp('(^| )_pc_=([^;]+)'));        
        if (match) {
            // If cookie with this name was found - try to parse the JSON value
            cookieValue = JSON.parse(match[2]);
        }
    }
    catch (e) {
        // By default - set value as empty object
        cookieValue = {};
    }
    if (!cookieValue) {
        // By default - set value as empty object
        cookieValue = {};
    }
    if (typeof specificName != "undefined") {
        // Get the specific value from the set
        if (typeof cookieValue[specificName] != "undefined") {
            return cookieValue[specificName];
        }
        return null;
    }
    return cookieValue;
}

/**
 * Hide the content block and reveal the hidden content below
 */
function unblockContent() {
    // Hide the content 
    blockElem = document.querySelector(".piano-content-lock");
    blockEnhancement = blockElem.closest(".piano-content-lock").style.display = 'none';

    // Get all blocked content
    blocked = document.querySelectorAll(".piano-content-lock ~*");

    // Unset each of these
    blocked.forEach( function(elem) {elem.style.display = 'revert'});
}

// Read all values from cookie
var cookieValues = pianoReadCustomVariableCookie();

for (var i in cookieValues) {
    // Set custom variables from cookie
    tp.push(['setCustomVariable', i, cookieValues[i]]);
}

/**
 * Validate Email
 */
function validateEmail(email) {
    return String(email)
    .toLowerCase()
    .match(
      /^(([^<>()[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/
    );
}</script>

    <h1 class="Page-headline">Several hundred ducks found dead from suspected bird flu along Lake Michigan</h1>



                        
    <h2 class="Page-subHeadline">The largest concentrations of sick mergansers were found Saturday at North Avenue Beach and Oak Street Beach. Other birds with symptoms were reported from Hyde Park to Wilmette between Friday and Sunday.</h2>

                                <div class="RichTextArticleBody RichTextBody">
                                    
                                        
                                    <p>Hundreds of red-breasted mergansers have been found either dead or sick over the past few days along Lake Michigan in Chicago and into the northern suburbs.</p><p>Officials suspect that highly contagious bird flu is the cause of the illnesses found in the mergansers, a species of diving duck that winters in the Great Lakes region.</p><p>Chicago Bird Collision Monitors, a volunteer conservation group, began receiving reports Friday from people finding large numbers of mergansers along the shores from Hyde Park to Wilmette, the organizations director, Annette Prince, said.</p><div class="RTEAdModule"><div class="HTLAds htlad-mobile_article_body_med_rec_dynamic" data-unit="/suntimes/chicago.suntimes.com/news" data-targeting="{}"></div></div><div class="RTEAdModule"><div class="HTLAds htlad-desktop_article_body" data-unit="/suntimes/chicago.suntimes.com/news" data-targeting="{}"></div></div><p>Two of the largest concentrations of sick mergansers  roughly 50 each  were found Saturday at North Avenue Beach and Oak Street Beach, Prince said. About the same number, if not more, were seen floating in the lake.</p><p>Prince estimated that around 200 to 300 infected mergansers were reported to her organization between Friday and Sunday.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center>
        <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop="large-2x1-notfixed">

        </div>
    </div><p>Its the first time that such a large number of mergansers has been suspected of bird flu infections, which has been on the rise in waterfowl and other birds throughout Illinois and the U.S. in recent months. </p><p>Last month, a <a class="Link"  href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2025/01/07/bald-eagle-bird-avian-flu-influenza-illinois-hinsdale-geese-duck-pandemic"  target="_blank" data-cms-ai="0"   >bald eagle</a> found in Hinsdale was euthanized after it appeared to be infected with bird flu, and in south suburban Matteson, a family-run farm lost its entire flock of <a class="Link"  href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/01/22/bird-flu-matteson-kakadoodle-farm-health-environment"  target="_blank" data-cms-ai="0"   >nearly 3,000 hens</a> to the disease.</p><div class="RTEAdModule"><div class="HTLAds htlad-mobile_article_body_med_rec_dynamic" data-unit="/suntimes/chicago.suntimes.com/news" data-targeting="{}"></div></div><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center>
        <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop="large-2x1-notfixed">
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-a00000" name="image-a00000" data-cms-ai="0"></a>

        data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e0cdbfa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1548x1018+0+0/resize/840x552!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd7%2Fbd%2F70d6669b4ef4bb17ba9fd5b68322%2Fscreenshot-2025-02-02-at-8-07-56-pm.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSI1NTJweCIgd2lkdGg9Ijg0MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4="

        <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Annette Prince, executive director of Chicago Bird Collision Monitors, holds a bald eagle found in Hinsdale that was euthanized after officials said it came down with bird flu.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tim Ramsey/Chicago Bird Collision Monitors<br></p></div></div>
    
</figure>

                        
                    
                
            
        </div>
    </div><p>The spread has seemed to reach out to another species here with the huge number of mergansers that are currently showing all the symptoms of bird flu, Prince said. This is a real change in the kind of bird and in the numbers that we had seen.</p><p>The majority of mergansers picked up by Princes organization were dead, she said, and the sick ones were not surviving well, but volunteers have picked them up to avoid other animals approaching them and getting infected.</p><p>Prince said seeing a merganser on land is the first clue that something may be amiss.</p><p>They really shouldnt be on land, she said. These birds only come on land when theyre in distress and no longer strong enough to fly or navigate the waters of the lakes, so its concerning if anyone notices these birds out of place from their typical aquatic environment.</p><div class="RTEAdModule"><div class="HTLAds htlad-mobile_article_body_med_rec_dynamic" data-unit="/suntimes/chicago.suntimes.com/news" data-targeting="{}"></div></div><div class="RTEAdModule"><div class="HTLAds htlad-desktop_article_body" data-unit="/suntimes/chicago.suntimes.com/news" data-targeting="{}"></div></div><p>A couple other mergansers sick with suspected bird flu were found over the weekend in parking lots at Lincoln Park Zoo and the Old Orchard Center in Skokie, Prince said.</p><p>Symptoms of bird flu include weakness, inability to stand up and move, tremors, green diarrhea and general respiratory and neurological problems.</p><p>We know this virus does very well in cold weather, and its going to stay around, as far as we know, until we get a break and warmer temperatures, so were worried that this could continue to spread to other species, other kinds of birds, Prince said.</p><p>The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported 67 cases of bird flu in humans since 2024, with almost all of the cases in people who worked with livestock or poultry. One human death from the virus has been reported  a Louisiana man with underlying health conditions who died last month.</p><div class="RTEAdModule"><div class="HTLAds htlad-mobile_article_body_med_rec_dynamic" data-unit="/suntimes/chicago.suntimes.com/news" data-targeting="{}"></div></div><p>As of Jan. 28, infections had been detected in more than 11,000 wild birds across the country since the outbreak started in 2022, according to the CDC.</p><p>Backyard and commercial poultry have suffered greatly from the disease, with nearly 150 million chickens, turkeys and other birds affected, the CDC said. It is also forcing farmers to slaughter millions of chickens a month, pushing U.S. egg prices to more than double their price from the summer of 2023.</p><p><i>Associated Press contributed.</i><br></p></div>

readabilityObject.title: Several hundred ducks found dead from suspected bird flu along Lake Michigan - Chicago Sun-Times
readabilityObject.content:
Hundreds of red-breasted mergansers have been found either dead or sick over the past few days along Lake Michigan in Chicago and into the northern suburbs.

Officials suspect that highly contagious bird flu is the cause of the illnesses found in the mergansers, a species of diving duck that winters in the Great Lakes region.

Chicago Bird Collision Monitors, a volunteer conservation group, began receiving reports Friday from people finding large numbers of mergansers along the shores from Hyde Park to Wilmette, the organizations director, Annette Prince, said.

Two of the largest concentrations of sick mergansers roughly 50 each were found Saturday at North Avenue Beach and Oak Street Beach, Prince said. About the same number, if not more, were seen floating in the lake.

Prince estimated that around 200 to 300 infected mergansers were reported to her organization between Friday and Sunday.

Its the first time that such a large number of mergansers has been suspected of bird flu infections, which has been on the rise in waterfowl and other birds throughout Illinois and the U.S. in recent months.

Last month, a bald eagle found in Hinsdale was euthanized after it appeared to be infected with bird flu, and in south suburban Matteson, a family-run farm lost its entire flock of nearly 3,000 hens to the disease.

The spread has seemed to reach out to another species here with the huge number of mergansers that are currently showing all the symptoms of bird flu, Prince said. This is a real change in the kind of bird and in the numbers that we had seen.

The majority of mergansers picked up by Princes organization were dead, she said, and the sick ones were not surviving well, but volunteers have picked them up to avoid other animals approaching them and getting infected.

Prince said seeing a merganser on land is the first clue that something may be amiss.

They really shouldnt be on land, she said. These birds only come on land when theyre in distress and no longer strong enough to fly or navigate the waters of the lakes, so its concerning if anyone notices these birds out of place from their typical aquatic environment.

A couple other mergansers sick with suspected bird flu were found over the weekend in parking lots at Lincoln Park Zoo and the Old Orchard Center in Skokie, Prince said.

Symptoms of bird flu include weakness, inability to stand up and move, tremors, green diarrhea and general respiratory and neurological problems.

We know this virus does very well in cold weather, and its going to stay around, as far as we know, until we get a break and warmer temperatures, so were worried that this could continue to spread to other species, other kinds of birds, Prince said.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported 67 cases of bird flu in humans since 2024, with almost all of the cases in people who worked with livestock or poultry. One human death from the virus has been reported a Louisiana man with underlying health conditions who died last month.

As of Jan. 28, infections had been detected in more than 11,000 wild birds across the country since the outbreak started in 2022, according to the CDC.

Backyard and commercial poultry have suffered greatly from the disease, with nearly 150 million chickens, turkeys and other birds affected, the CDC said. It is also forcing farmers to slaughter millions of chickens a month, pushing U.S. egg prices to more than double their price from the summer of 2023.

Associated Press contributed.
readabilityObject.textContent:
Hundreds of red-breasted mergansers have been found either dead or sick over the past few days along Lake Michigan in Chicago and into the northern suburbs.Officials suspect that highly contagious bird flu is the cause of the illnesses found in the mergansers, a species of diving duck that winters in the Great Lakes region.Chicago Bird Collision Monitors, a volunteer conservation group, began receiving reports Friday from people finding large numbers of mergansers along the shores from Hyde Park to Wilmette, the organizations director, Annette Prince, said.Two of the largest concentrations of sick mergansers  roughly 50 each  were found Saturday at North Avenue Beach and Oak Street Beach, Prince said. About the same number, if not more, were seen floating in the lake.Prince estimated that around 200 to 300 infected mergansers were reported to her organization between Friday and Sunday.
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    


                        
                    
                
            
        Its the first time that such a large number of mergansers has been suspected of bird flu infections, which has been on the rise in waterfowl and other birds throughout Illinois and the U.S. in recent months. Last month, a bald eagle found in Hinsdale was euthanized after it appeared to be infected with bird flu, and in south suburban Matteson, a family-run farm lost its entire flock of nearly 3,000 hens to the disease.
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        Annette Prince, executive director of Chicago Bird Collision Monitors, holds a bald eagle found in Hinsdale that was euthanized after officials said it came down with bird flu.Tim Ramsey/Chicago Bird Collision Monitors
    


                        
                    
                
            
        The spread has seemed to reach out to another species here with the huge number of mergansers that are currently showing all the symptoms of bird flu, Prince said. This is a real change in the kind of bird and in the numbers that we had seen.The majority of mergansers picked up by Princes organization were dead, she said, and the sick ones were not surviving well, but volunteers have picked them up to avoid other animals approaching them and getting infected.Prince said seeing a merganser on land is the first clue that something may be amiss.They really shouldnt be on land, she said. These birds only come on land when theyre in distress and no longer strong enough to fly or navigate the waters of the lakes, so its concerning if anyone notices these birds out of place from their typical aquatic environment.A couple other mergansers sick with suspected bird flu were found over the weekend in parking lots at Lincoln Park Zoo and the Old Orchard Center in Skokie, Prince said.Symptoms of bird flu include weakness, inability to stand up and move, tremors, green diarrhea and general respiratory and neurological problems.We know this virus does very well in cold weather, and its going to stay around, as far as we know, until we get a break and warmer temperatures, so were worried that this could continue to spread to other species, other kinds of birds, Prince said.The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported 67 cases of bird flu in humans since 2024, with almost all of the cases in people who worked with livestock or poultry. One human death from the virus has been reported  a Louisiana man with underlying health conditions who died last month.As of Jan. 28, infections had been detected in more than 11,000 wild birds across the country since the outbreak started in 2022, according to the CDC.Backyard and commercial poultry have suffered greatly from the disease, with nearly 150 million chickens, turkeys and other birds affected, the CDC said. It is also forcing farmers to slaughter millions of chickens a month, pushing U.S. egg prices to more than double their price from the summer of 2023.Associated Press contributed.
